The markup percentage can be calculated using the formula:

\[
\text{Markup Percentage} = \left( \frac{\text{Selling Price} - \text{Cost}}{\text{Cost}} \right) \times 100
\]

If Maria offers a $3 discount, she should recalculate her markup based on either the adjusted selling price or the reduced cost. If the discount affects the selling price, the new markup would be calculated as:

\[
\text{New Markup Percentage} = \left( \frac{\text{Original Selling Price} - 3}{\text{Cost} - 3} \right) \times 100
\]

For example, if her original selling price is $70 and cost is $50:

- Original Markup: \(\left( \frac{70 - 50}{50} \right) \times 100 = 40\%\)

- After a $3 discount:

  \[
  \text{New Markup} = \left( \frac{67}{47} \right) \times 100 \approx 142.55\%
  \]

This recalculated markup would reflect the new effective price after the discount.
